title: Add explicit config validation with actionable error messages
description:
Background:
The config module defines `ValidationError` but currently does not run a dedicated validation pass after parse. Invalid-but-parseable configs can slip through until execution.

Why this matters:
- Users get late/runtime failures instead of immediate feedback.
- Errors do not always point to the exact hook entry causing problems.

Relevant files:
- `crates/git-smee-core/src/config.rs`
- `crates/git-smee-cli/src/main.rs` (where config load errors are surfaced)

Implementation notes:
- Add a `validate()` pass on `SmeeConfig` and invoke it during load.
- Validate at least:
  - command string is not empty/whitespace
  - hook table entries are structurally valid
  - unexpected fields are rejected (`deny_unknown_fields` where appropriate)
- Include hook name and entry index in validation errors for faster debugging.

title: Make init/install safe for existing files (managed marker + --force)
description:
Background:
`git smee init` and hook installation currently write files directly, which can overwrite existing user-managed `.git-smee.toml` or hook scripts.

Why this matters:
- Risk of clobbering hand-written hook scripts.
- Risk of destroying an existing config file unexpectedly.
- Harder adoption in repositories with pre-existing hook workflows.

Relevant files:
- `crates/git-smee-cli/src/main.rs`
- `crates/git-smee-core/src/installer.rs`
- `crates/git-smee-core/src/scripts/hook_template_unix`
- `crates/git-smee-core/src/scripts/hook_template_windows`
- `README.md` command docs

Implementation notes:
- Detect whether an existing hook/config file is already managed by git-smee (using the managed header marker).
- Default behavior should avoid overwriting unmanaged files.
- Add `--force` to allow explicit overwrite.

title: Replace hard bash dependency in executor with portable shell
description:
Background:
Runtime command execution on Unix currently spawns bash -c for every hook command, while generated hook wrappers use /usr/bin/env sh. The project README advertises lightweight cross-platform behavior, but requiring bash is stricter than required and can fail on environments that only provide POSIX sh (for example minimal containers).

Why this matters:
- Hook execution can fail even though install succeeded.
- Behavior differs between wrapper script shell and executor shell.
- This is a portability bug for Unix-like systems without bash.

Relevant files:
- crates/git-smee-core/src/platform.rs
- crates/git-smee-core/src/executor.rs
- crates/git-smee-core/tests (add regression coverage)

Implementation notes:
- Use a more portable default shell for Unix command execution (for example sh -c), or add a robust fallback strategy.
- Keep Windows behavior unchanged.
- Ensure error messages make shell-launch failures actionable.

title: Improve executor error modeling for spawn vs exit failures
description:
Background:
`executor::Error` includes `NonSuccessfulExitStatus(std::io::Error)`, but `std::io::Error` in this path represents command spawn/setup failures, not non-zero process exits. Non-zero exits are modeled separately by `ExecutionFailed`.

Why this matters:
- Error names can mislead maintainers and users.
- Diagnostics lack enough context (e.g., which command failed to spawn).

Relevant file:
- `crates/git-smee-core/src/executor.rs`

Implementation notes:
- Rename/refactor error variants so names match actual failure mode.
- Include command text (or a redacted representation) in spawn failure errors.
- Keep exit-code failures and signal terminations distinct.

title: Add Windows CI job for build/test coverage
description:
Background:
Current CI in `.github/workflows/ci.yml` runs only on `ubuntu-latest`. Platform-specific regressions (especially Windows shell/permissions behavior) can slip through undetected.

Why this matters:
- The project claims cross-platform support, but CI does not verify it.
- Recent code paths rely on OS-specific abstractions (`Platform`, hook templates).

Relevant file:
- .github/workflows/ci.yml

Implementation notes:
- Add a Windows job (at least stable toolchain) that runs build + tests.
- Keep runtime reasonable (can skip coverage on Windows).
- Consider scoping unstable tests if any are shell-dependent and currently Unix-specific.

title: Refactor executor tests to be deterministic and cross-platform
description:
Background:
Executor tests currently rely on shell commands such as `sleep` and `echo`, and on timing assertions with narrow thresholds. This can be flaky and platform-specific (especially Windows).

Why this matters:
- Inconsistent CI behavior across OSes.
- Tests may fail due to host load rather than logic regressions.

Relevant files:
- `crates/git-smee-core/src/executor.rs`
- `crates/git-smee-core/src/platform.rs` (if injection points are added)

Implementation notes:
- Introduce an abstraction for command execution (trait or injectable function) so tests can use a fake runner.
- Keep production behavior identical while making tests independent of system shell tools and wall-clock timing.

title: Add hook-script escaping regression tests for special paths
description:
Background:
Hook scripts interpolate absolute executable and config paths into shell templates. The code includes dedicated escaping helpers for Unix and Windows, but current tests mostly assert that plain paths are present. There is no regression coverage for paths containing shell-sensitive characters like single quotes, percent signs, or spaces with quoting edge cases.

Why this matters:
- Incorrect escaping can make installed hooks fail at runtime.
- Path edge cases often appear in CI workspaces and user home directories.
- Testing gaps can hide cross-platform regressions.

Relevant files:
- crates/git-smee-core/src/installer.rs
- crates/git-smee-core/src/scripts/hook_template_unix
- crates/git-smee-core/src/scripts/hook_template_windows
- crates/git-smee-cli/tests/cli_integration.rs

Implementation notes:
- Add focused unit tests for shell_single_quote and cmd_escape helper behavior.
- Add at least one integration-style assertion that generated hook content includes correctly escaped values for tricky paths.
- Keep tests deterministic and platform-gated where needed.

title: Reject unknown hook names in .git-smee.toml
description:
Background:
`SmeeConfig` currently flattens hook tables into `HashMap<LifeCyclePhase, Vec<HookDefinition>>` and `LifeCyclePhase` includes `Unknown` via `#[serde(other)]`. Unknown hook keys can silently deserialize as `Unknown`, and multiple unknown keys can overwrite each other in the map.

Why this matters:
- User typos in hook names are not surfaced clearly.
- Config data can be lost silently when multiple unknown keys collapse into one map key.
- Installer may emit a literal `unknown` hook script.

Relevant files:
- `crates/git-smee-core/src/config.rs`
- `crates/git-smee-core/src/installer.rs`

Implementation notes:
- Remove the silent fallback path for unknown lifecycle phases during config parse.
- Return a precise parse/validation error that includes the unknown hook name.
- Keep behavior for known lifecycle phases unchanged.

title: Allow git-smee --help outside Git repositories
description:
Background:
`main()` calls `repository::ensure_in_repo_root()` before parsing CLI args. That means `--help` and `--version` fail unless the current directory is inside a Git repo.

Repro:
1. Build binary (`cargo build -p git-smee-cli`)
2. Run from a non-repo dir: `/path/to/git-smee --help`
3. Current behavior: exits with `Error: NotInGitRepository` instead of printing help.

Why this matters:
- Standard CLI UX expects help/version to work anywhere.
- It blocks discoverability and makes shell completion workflows awkward.

Relevant file:
- crates/git-smee-cli/src/main.rs

title: Make CLI errors user-friendly instead of Rust debug variants
description:
Background:
Running repository-dependent commands outside a git repo currently prints internal Rust enum variants like Error: NotInGitRepository instead of human-readable error text. Similar raw variant output appears for install/init safety errors and config validation failures.

Repro:
1. Build binary with cargo build -p git-smee-cli.
2. Run from a non-repo directory: git-smee install.
3. Current output includes internal variant names.

Why this matters:
- End users see implementation details instead of actionable guidance.
- Error UX is inconsistent with README messaging and reduces trust in CLI polish.

Relevant files:
- crates/git-smee-cli/src/main.rs
- crates/git-smee-core/src/repository.rs
- crates/git-smee-core/src/installer.rs
- crates/git-smee-core/src/config.rs

Implementation notes:
- Ensure top-level error rendering uses Display messages from error types, not Debug variant names.
- Preserve non-zero exit codes on failure.
- Add contextual hints for common user mistakes where useful (outside repo, missing config file, unknown hook name).

title: Fix Unix-only platform import that breaks Windows builds
description:
Background:
`crates/git-smee-core/src/platform.rs` imports `std::os::unix::fs::PermissionsExt` unconditionally at module scope, while the crate advertises Windows support. This API is unavailable on Windows targets and can cause compile failures before runtime branching is reached.

Why this matters:
- Cross-platform promise in README can be broken at compile time.
- This can block release pipelines and contributors on Windows.

Relevant file:
- crates/git-smee-core/src/platform.rs

Implementation notes:
- Gate Unix-specific imports and permission logic with `#[cfg(unix)]`.
- Keep Windows behavior as no-op for `make_executable`, but ensure the whole module compiles on Windows targets.

title: Add configurable config path support and robust hook command resolution
description:
Background:
The CLI always reads `.git-smee.toml` from repo root and installed hook templates call `git smee run <hook>` via shell PATH lookup.

Why this matters:
- Teams may want alternate config locations for migration/testing.
- Hook execution can fail in restricted environments where PATH does not include the git-smee binary.

Relevant files:
- `crates/git-smee-cli/src/main.rs`
- `crates/git-smee-core/src/installer.rs`
- `crates/git-smee-core/src/scripts/hook_template_unix`
- `crates/git-smee-core/src/scripts/hook_template_windows`
- `README.md`

Implementation notes:
- Add `--config <path>` and optional `GIT_SMEE_CONFIG` fallback.
- Resolve precedence explicitly (flag > env > default).
- Improve generated hook scripts so they can reliably invoke git-smee even when PATH is limited (for example via absolute executable path or a validated fallback strategy).

title: Support worktrees and core.hooksPath when installing hooks
description:
Background:
`FileSystemHookInstaller` currently assumes hooks always live under `<repo>/.git/hooks`. That assumption fails for Git worktrees and repositories with `core.hooksPath` configured.

Why this matters:
- `git smee install` can write hook files to the wrong location.
- Users can think hooks are installed while Git executes a different hooks directory.

Relevant files:
- `crates/git-smee-core/src/installer.rs`
- `crates/git-smee-core/src/repository.rs`
- optionally `crates/git-smee-cli/src/main.rs` if CLI wiring needs changes

Implementation notes:
- Resolve the effective hooks directory through Git metadata (for example `git rev-parse --git-path hooks`) instead of hardcoding `.git/hooks`.
- Ensure logic works for standard repos, worktrees, and explicit `core.hooksPath`.
- Preserve clear error messages when the resolved hooks path does not exist or is not writable.
